1 Weyl Algebra Definition 1.1 (Weyl algebra) The Weyl algebra \(W_p\) and one site is finitely generated by \(U_{(p)}, V_{(p)}\), subject to \[ U^p = V^p = 1, \quad VU = \omega UV \] It generates the Schwinger basis indexed by \(\xi = (q, p) \in \mathbb Z^p\times \mathbb Z^p\): \[ J_\xi = \bar \omega^{\xi_1\xi_2/2} V^{q} U^p \] The \(N\)-site Weyl algebra is defined by \(W_p(N)=W_P^{\otimes n}\). For example, for \(p=2\) we obtain the Pauli basis \(V=\sigma_x, U=\sigma_z\). Proposition 1.1 (Weyl Lie relation) Let \(\xi=(q, p)\) equipped with addition modulo \(p\) and \(\xi_1\times \xi_2 = q_1p_2 - q_2p_1\), then \[ [J_{\xi_1}, J_{\xi_2}] = 2i \sin \left( \dfrac\pi p \xi_1\times \xi_2 \right) J_{\xi_1+\xi_2} \] Proceeding to compute the commutator, note that \(UV = \bar \omega VU\), then \[\begin{align} [J_{\xi_1}, J_{\xi_2}] &= [\bar \omega^{q_1p_1/2} V^{q_1} U^{p_1}, \bar \omega^{q_2 p_2/2} V^{q_2} U^{p_2}] \\ &= \omega^{-\frac 1 2 (q_1p_1 + q_2 p_2)} (V^{q_1} U^{p_1} V^{q_2} U^{p_2} - V^{q_2} U^{p_2}V^{q_1} U^{p_1}) \\ &= \omega^{-\frac 1 2 (q_1p_1 + q_2 p_2)} V^{q_1 + q_2} U^{p_1 + p_2} (\omega^{-p_1 q_2} - \omega^{-q_1p_2}) \tag{1.1} \end{align}\] On the other hand, reminding that \(\xi_1\times \xi_2 = q_1p_2 - q_2p_1\), we obtain \[\begin{align} 2i \sin \left(\dfrac\pi p \xi_1\times \xi_2 \right) J_{\xi_1+\xi_2} &= \left[\exp\left(\dfrac{i\pi}{p} \xi_1\times \xi_2\right) - \exp\left(-\dfrac{i\pi}{p} \xi_1\times \xi_2\right)\right] \omega^{-\frac 1 2 (q_1+q_2)(p_1+p_2)} V^{q_1+q_2}U^{p_1+p_2} \\ &= \left(\omega^{\xi_1\times \xi_2/2} - \omega^{-\xi_1\times \xi_2/2}\right) \omega^{-\frac 1 2 (q_1+q_2)(p_1+p_2)}V^{q_1+q_2} U^{p_1+p_2} \end{align}\] In the first term \(\omega^{\xi_1\times \xi_2/2}\), the \(+q_1p_2\) cancels with that from \(\omega^{-\frac 1 2 (q_1+q_2)(p_1+p_2)}\), leaving \(\omega^{-\frac 1 2 (q_1p_q + q_2p_2) - q_2p_1}\), matching the first term in (1.1), as desired. The same goes for the second term. Proposition 1.2 (canonical decomposition of Weyl algebras) Let \(p=p_1p_2\) relative primes, then \[ W_{p_1}\otimes W_{p_2} \cong W_p \] under the mapping extended multiplicatively from the generators \[ \varphi\, U_{(p_1)} \otimes U_{(p_2)} = U_{(p)}, \quad \varphi\, V_{(p_1)} \otimes V_{(p_2)} = V_{(p)}^{(p_1+p_2)} \] Note that since \(p_1, p_2\) are relative primes, \(U\otimes U\) and \(V\otimes V\) does generate \(W_{p_1}\otimes W_{p_2}\). Explicitly, we obtain the embedding isomorphisms \[\begin{align} \varphi \, U^{p_2}_{(p_1)} \otimes U^{p_2}_{(p_2)} &= \varphi \, U^{p_2}_{(p_1)} \otimes 1 = U_{(p)}^{p_2} \\ \varphi \, V^{p_2}_{(p_1)} \otimes V^{p_2}_{(p_2)} &= \varphi \, V^{p_2}_{(p_1)} \otimes 1 = V_{(p)}^{(p_1+p_2)p_2} = V_{(p)}^{p_2^2} \end{align}\] Weyl parafermions Definition 1.2 (Weyl parafermion generators) Fixing \(p\) and \(N\), we can define an alternate set of generators of \(W_p(N)\) by \[ \Gamma_j = U_1\dots U_{j-1}V_j, \quad \Delta_j = U_1\dots U_{j-1} (U_j V_j) = \Gamma_j U_j \] Set \(\gamma_1, \dots \gamma_{2n} = \Gamma_1, \Delta_1, \Gamma_2, \Delta_2, \dots\), then we obtain \[ \gamma_j \gamma_k = [\delta_{jk} + (1-\delta_{jk}) \omega] \gamma_k \gamma_j, \quad \Gamma_j^p = \Delta_j^p = 1, \quad \gamma_j^\dagger= \gamma_j^{p-1} \] One can recover the Weyl generators by \[ U_j = \Gamma_j^\dagger\Delta_j, \quad V_j = \Gamma_j \prod_{k=1}^{j-1} U_k^\dagger = \Gamma_j \prod_{k=1}^{j-1} \Delta_k^\dagger\Gamma_k \] For the case of \(p=2\), we obtain \(\Gamma_j = Z_1\dots Z_{j-1}X_j\) and \(\Delta_j = -iZ_1 \dots Z_{j-1}Y_j\). For a more comprehensive treatment of duality, see (Cobanera, Ortiz, and Nussinov 2011). Definition 1.3 (parafermion self-duality) We are interested in the following duality for the \(p\)-clock model (which has a transparant parafermion interpretation). Fixing \(N\) sites, consider the von-Neumann algebra \(\mathcal A\) generated by \(\{U_1, \dots, U_n, V_1V_2^\dagger, V_2V_3^\dagger, \dots, V_{N-1}V_N^\dagger, V_N\}\). Let \(r(j_{1\leq j\leq N}) = N+1-j\) (denoting the reverse order) and define \[\begin{align} \Phi_d(U_1) &= V^\dagger_N, \quad \Phi_d(V_N) = U_1 \\ \Phi_d(U_j) &= V^\dagger_{r(j)} V_{r(j)+1}, \quad \Phi_d(V_j V_{j+1}^\dagger) = U_{r(j)} \end{align}\] Definition 1.4 (Artin braid group) The braid group \(B_L\) on \(L\) modes is the free group in generators \(\sigma_1, \dots, \sigma_{L-1}\) subject to \(\sigma_k \sigma_{k+1}\sigma_k = \sigma_{k+1}\sigma_k \sigma_{k+1}\) and \(\sigma_k\sigma_l = \sigma_l\sigma_k\) if \(|k-l|\geq 2\). Fock parafermions Here, we construct the Fock space of indistinguishable particles upon specifying: The state space \(\mathcal H\) of a single particle (orbitals it can occupy). A rule to multiply \(N\) single-particle states to generate a \(N\)-body state with the correct exchange and exclusion statistics. Let \(n_E\geq 2\) denote the exclusion parameter, the Fock space \(\mathcal F\) on \(M\) sites is \[ \mathcal F = \bigoplus_{N=0} \text{span of } |n_1, \dots, n_M\rangle\text{ subject to } \sum_{r=1}^M n_r = N \] We abbreviate the notation \(|n_j\rangle\) denotes \(n_j\) particles in the \(j\)-th entry, and \(|n_j, n_k\rangle\) with \((n_j, n_k)\) particles in the \((j, k)\)-th sites, and so on. We next proceed to make \(\mathcal F\) an algebra by specifying multiplication: Proposition 1.3 (multiplication on Fock space) Define \(|1_j\rangle=|n_j=1\rangle\) and the following rules for multiplication: \(|1_{\forall j}\rangle^{n_E} = 0\), where \(n_E\) is the exclusion parameter. \(|n_1, \dots n_M\rangle= |1_1\rangle^{n_1} |1_2\rangle^{n_2} \dots |1_M\rangle^{n_M}\). \(|1_j\rangle|1_{k\neq j}\rangle= \omega |1_k\rangle|1_j\rangle\implies |n_j\rangle|n_k\rangle= \omega^{n_kn_j} |n_k\rangle|n_j\rangle= |n_j, n_k\rangle\) for \(j\leq k\). Every operator commuting with every other operator in \(\mathcal F\) is a scalar multiple of the Fock vacuum. Definition 1.5 (creation and annihilation operators) Define the creation operator \(C_j^\dagger: \mathcal F\to \mathcal F\) by extending \[ C_j^\dagger|n_1, \dots, n_M\rangle= |1_j\rangle|n_1, \dots, n_M\rangle = \omega^{\sum_{k=1}^{j-1} n_k} |n_1, \dots, n_j+1, \dots, n_M\rangle \] In lieu of the given inner product, its adjoint annihilation operator \(C_j\) is \[\begin{align} \langle m_1, \dots, m_M| (C_j |n_1, \dots, n_M\rangle) &= (C_j^\dagger|m_1, \dots m_M\rangle)^\dagger|n_1, \dots, n_M\rangle\\ &= \omega^{\sum_{k=1}^{j-1} m_k} \langle m_1, \dots, m_j+1, m_M| n_1, \dots, n_M\rangle\\ &= \omega^{\sum_{k=1}^{j-1} n_k} \delta_{m_1n_1}\dots \delta_{(m_j+1)n_j} \dots \delta_{m_M n_M} \\ &= \omega^{\sum_{k=1}^{j-1} n_k}\delta_{m_1n_1}\dots \delta_{m_j(n_j-1)} \dots \delta_{m_M n_M} \\ C_j |n_1, \dots, n_M\rangle &= \omega^{\sum_{k=1}^{j-1} n_k}|n_1, \dots, n_j-1, n_M\rangle \end{align}\] The algebra of the creation and annihilation operators thus are \[\begin{align} C_j^{\dagger p} &= C_j^p = 0, \quad C_j^\dagger C_{k>j}^\dagger= \omega C_k^\dagger C_j^\dagger, \quad C_j C_k = \omega C_k C_j \end{align}\] Canonical transforms Recalling the Pf majorana algebra: \[ \gamma_j^p = 1, \quad \gamma_j^\dagger= \gamma_j^{p-1}, \quad \gamma_j \gamma_k = \omega^{s_{jk}} \gamma_k \gamma_j, \quad s_{jk} = \begin{cases} 1 & j < k \\ -1 & j>k \\ 0 & j = k \end{cases} \] For the case \(p=2\), consider the unitary mapping ansatz \(\varphi\, \gamma_j = A_{jk}\gamma_k\), we have the following equations: \[\begin{align} 1 &= (\varphi\, \gamma_j)^2 = A_{ja} A_{jb} \gamma_a \gamma_b = (A^TA)_{ab} \gamma_a \gamma_b \implies A^TA = I \\ A_{jk}^* \gamma_j &= A_{jk} \gamma_j \implies A_{jk}\in \mathbb R\\ (\varphi\, \gamma_j)(\varphi\, \gamma_k) &= \omega^{s_{jk}} (\varphi\, \gamma_k)(\varphi\, \gamma_j) \implies \end{align}\] Bibliography Cobanera, Emilio, Gerardo Ortiz, and Zohar Nussinov. 2011. “The Bond-Algebraic Approach to Dualities.” Advances in Physics 60 (5): 679–798.

2 Tensor Networks and Geometry Reference: Tensor networks and geometry (Evenbly and Vidal 2011). This works presents a perspective on the entanglement and correlator properties of tensor-network states by examining the geometry of the tensor network ansatz. Critical v. non-critical systems Definition 2.1 (two-point correlator) Given local operators \(P_{x_1}, Q_{x_2}\) supported on sites \(x_1, x_2\in \mathcal L\), the two-point correlator is defined as \[ C(x_1, x_2) = \langle P_{x_1}Q_{x_2}\rangle- \langle P_{x_1}\rangle\langle Q_{x_2}\rangle \] Where \(\langle O\rangle\) denotes the expectation w.r.t. the ground state of a given Hamiltonian. Known results for the decay of correlators, when the Hamiltonian features local interactions: Gapped Hamiltonian (i.e. finite separation between ground and excited spectrums): \[ C(x_1, x_2) \approx e^{|x_1 - x_2|/\xi} \] here \(\xi\geq 0\) is the correlation length. Such systems are also known as non-critical systems Gapless Hamiltonian i.e. critical systems: \[ C(x_1, x_2) \approx |x_1 - x_2|^{-q} \] Definition 2.2 (entanglement entropy) Given a block \(A\subset \mathcal L\) of the lattice, the entanglement entropy is \[ S(A) = -\mathrm{tr}(\rho_A \log_2 \rho_A) \] The following results are also known for the entanglement entropy in \(D\) dimensions: For gapped systems, \(S(A) \approx |\partial A| \approx L^{D-1}\). Gapless systems exhibit mixed behavior: For Fermi surface dimension \(\Gamma < D-1\), the boundary law holds. Systems with \(\Gamma = D - 1\) exhibit a logarithmic correction to the boundary law: \[ S(A) \approx L^{D-1}\log L \] Connection to tensor networks Assuming a generic homogeneous tensor network i.e. all tensors of the same type are copies of a single tensor, with coefficients chosen randomly, connectivity determines important properties about the correlators and entanglement entropy. Proposition 2.1 (geodesic distance and correlators) Given two sites \(x_1, x_2\in \mathcal L\) with geodesic distance \(D(x_1, x_2)\), \[ C(x_1, x_2) \approx e^{-\alpha D(x_1, x_2)} \] Proof: The transfer matrix which determines contraction has positive eigenvalues, maximally \(1\), and the correlator is obtained by evaluating an expression involving the \(D(x_1, x_2)\)-th power of the transfer matrix. This implies the following correlator bounds for MPS and MERA: \(C_{\mathrm{MPS}}(x_1, x_2) \approx e^{-\alpha |x_1 - x_2|}\). \(C_{\mathrm{MERA}}(x_1, x_2) \approx e^{-\alpha \log_2 |x_1 - x_2|} \approx |x_1 - x_2|^{-q}\). Proposition 2.2 (entanglement entropy and boundary size) Let \(\bar A = \mathcal L - A\) denote the complementary system with \(|A|\leq |\bar A|\), given a Schmidt decomposition of the ground state w.r.t. the partition with Schmidt rank \(\chi\): \[ |\psi\rangle= \sum_{j=1}^{\chi} \lambda_j |\psi^A_j\rangle|\psi^{\bar A}_j\rangle, \quad \sum \lambda_j^2 = 1, \quad \chi\leq |A| \] The entanglement entropy is maximized when \(\lambda_{\forall j} = 1/\sqrt \chi\) \[ S(A) = -\sum_{j=1}^{\chi} \lambda_j^2 \log \dfrac 1 {\lambda_j^2} \leq \log_2 \chi \] Given \(A\subset \mathcal L\), for every partition \(\Omega_A\sqcup \Omega_B\) of the nodes in the tensor network with such that \(\Omega_A\) contains all the free legs of \(A\), we can upper-bound the entanglement entropy according to \[ S(A) \leq |\partial \Omega_A| \log_2\chi \] where \(|\partial \Omega_A|\) is the number of legs across the cut \(\Omega_A\sqcup \Omega_B\), and \(\chi\) is the bond dimension of the homogeneous tensor. In 1D-MPS, \(|\Omega_A|=2\), yielding the saturation of entanglement entropy. In 1D-MERA, \(|\Omega_A| = \sum_{z=1}^{\log L} 2 \approx \log L\), yielding the logarithmic violation. In \(D>1\) MERA, \(|\Omega_A| = \sum_{z=1}^{\log L} L^{D-1}/2^z \approx L^{D-1}\). Only the shortest length-scale (i.e. least coarse-graining) contributes meaningfully to the entropy. Branched MERA The concluding section of (Evenbly and Vidal 2011) mentioned the idea of branching, subsequently developed in (Evenbly and Vidal 2014), Scaling of entanglement entropy in the (branching) MERA. The main contributions are: Generalization of MERA by introducing a branching parameter \(b\), with \(b=1\) corresponding to the known MERA. The \(b=2^{D-1}\)-branched MERA supports logarithmic area law in \(D>1\) dimensions: \(S(A) \approx L^{D-1}\log L\). Numerical evidence that the upper-bound for entanglement entropy is saturated up to leading order. The paper identifies two regimes in the coarse-graining procedure: Shrinking regime: the size of the coarse-grained block shrinks as a result of the coarse-graining isometry. At this scale, the coarse-grained system is entangled with the complementary system. Stationary regime: the size of the coarse-grained block stays constant (or vanishes). At this scale and above, the coarse-grained system no longer contributes entanglement. The total entanglement entropy can be computed as \[ S(A) \propto |\partial \Omega_A| = \sum_{z=0}^{\bar z} |\partial A_z| \] where \(\partial A_z\) is the size of the boundary of the coarse-grain of \(A\) at scale \(z\). For the traditional MERA on lattice dimension \(D\), each coarse-graining maps \(L \mapsto L/2\), so \[ |\partial A_{z+1}| = |\partial A_z| 2^{-(D-1)} \] with \(A\) being a hypercube of size \(L\), we have \(\bar z = \log_2 L\) and \(|\partial A_z|=L^{D-1}/2^z\). In order to yield the desired \(L^{D-1}\log L\) entropy, we need to multiplicatively correct \(|\partial A_z| \mapsto |\partial A_z| 2^{(D-1)z}\) to obtain logarithmic violation \[ S(A) \propto \sum_{z=0}^{\bar z} \dfrac{|\partial A_z| 2^{(D-1)z}}{2^{(D-1)z}} = L^{D-1} \log_2 L \] This corresponds to introducing \(2^{(D-1)}\) copies of the coarse-grained site at each coarse-graining step.
